conclusion: The problem involves determining the height that object A rises and the stiffness coefficient k2 of the light spring C.
The mass of object A is m = 2 kg, the spring constant of spring B is k1 = 200 N/m, the initial position of the right endpoint of spring C is at a, and the distance ab = 60 cm = 0.6 m.
The tension force of spring B on object A is equal to the gravitational force of A, so T = mg = 2 × 9.8 = 19.6 N.
The extension in spring B is calculated as k1 x = T, so 200 x = 19.6, leading to x = 19.6 / 200 = 0.098 m = 9.8 cm.
The initial position of spring B is such that it is not stretched or compressed, so the new length of spring B is L_B + 0.098 m.
The extension in spring C is the horizontal component of the displacement, which is 0.6 m.
Using the Pythagorean theorem, the vertical component of the displacement (height A rises) is calculated as h = sqrt((0.6)^2 - (0.098)^2) ≈ sqrt(0.36 - 0.009604) ≈ sqrt(0.350396) ≈ 0.592 m.
The height that object A rises is h = 0.592 m.
The tension in spring C is the same as the tension in spring B, which is 19.6 N.
The stiffness coefficient k2 of spring C is calculated as k2 h = T, so k2 × 0.592 = 19.6, leading to k2 = 19.6 / 0.592 ≈ 33.1 N/m.
The stiffness coefficient k2 of the light spring C is k2 = 33.1 N/m.
The final answers are: the height that object A rises is 0.592 m, and the stiffness coefficient k2 of the light spring C is 33.1 N/m.
